Chapter 3 Software and Hardware 3.1 Software 3.2 Computer processes

Chapter 3 Software and Hardware This is a great question I have been playing around with to help learn how to use the diagrammeR package. The question is: What is the difference between software and hardware? ## -- Attaching packages ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.2.1 -- ## v ggplot2 3.2.1 v purrr 0.3.3 ## v tibble 2.1.3 v dplyr 0.8.3 ## v tidyr 1.0.0 v stringr 1.4.0 ## v readr 1.3.1 v forcats 0.4.0 ## -- Conflicts -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x purrr::is_null() masks testthat::is_null() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() ## x dplyr::matches() masks tidyr::matches(), testthat::matches() ## ## Attaching package: 'kableExtra' ## The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr': ## ## group_rows I thought that is was an obvious difference. Hardware is the stuff that makes the software work. For example, RAM is hardware, word is software? Software Hardware R RAM word CPU excel Processors 3.1 Software But the problem is when somebody knows the interface (software that uses many types of software). Examples of this are programs like RStudio, vs-code and other such programs. This is because they are a single piece of software that uses “heaps” of other software. But then each bit of software such as GIT and R can be accessed by many different types of software…so is R not just hardware then? And now the question becomes about the definition of what software and hardware are… Software Hardware R RAM word CPU excel Processors 3.1.1 RStudio But the problem is when somebody knows the interface (software that uses many types of software). Examples of this are programs like RStudio, vs-code and other such programs. This is because they are a single piece of software that uses “heaps” of other software. 3.1.2 ‘vs-code’ But then each bit of software such as GIT and R can be accessed by many different types of software…so is R not just hardware then? 3.1.3 R 3.2 Computer processes 3.2.1 RStudio This is an example of a piece of software. It needs your computer (hardware) to run so therefore it is software. Just the same as R….but not really. 3.2.1.1 A simple Rscript But this is not really what is happening. For example this is the RMarkdown figure for this process: 3.2.2 v3 3.2.3 v4

likscale.html
Chapter 5 Likert Scales 5.1 The problem 5.2 Method 5.3 Flow diagram

Chapter 5 Likert Scales 5.1 The problem To build a sampling design that accounts for the issues and nature of data collection of foriegn bank movements using person-to-person == surveys. 5.2 Method Here we want to address the key objectives of our reseach by collecting data in an unbias and representative way. To understand the true underlying trends in the data a pilot study with a large enough sample is explored below. Here we have a difficult question to address due to the bias in the data capture method. This is really interesting and challenging from a statistical prospective. This is also a problem that the qualitative approach fails to address (waiting to see what others say about this..?) Here is a step-by-step to approach to this research in a quantativite way: The questions are grouped into sets of questions that all address a general objective or question the research has. We can first see if these patterns are true for the responses. These are as follows: There are several issues with this because the data collected is often non-normal and needs to be transformed. The first step however is to simply visualise the data in a way that we will also be fitting the statistical models. There is some simple dataset transformations that can be done to make it easier to work with the data in the plotting functions. 5.3 Flow diagram Here I think we should add the relationship to each question and the proposed hypothesis… 5.3.1 v1 5.3.2 v2 A similar automatic report can be generated using by using the DIY_ANOVA app here. It consists of a reduced version of the following report and sections. 5.3.3 v3 5.3.4 v4
mixed.html
Chapter 6 Mixed regression models 6.1 Models

Chapter 6 Mixed regression models 6.1 Models Mixed models essentially start with sample mean differences between groups and then add additional complexity in favour of poor fitting models. You can write out models and variable relationships using statistical equations such as \(y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1(x_i)\) where the variables can be collected either through direct questions or transformed data from the orginal questions. What does it look like in a diagram explaining how the variables are proposed to be similar? Example below: 6.1.1 Constant only \[ outcome = \beta_0\] 6.1.2 Single predictor \[ outcome = \beta_0 + \beta_1(sex_i)\] 6.1.3 Multi-level v1 For example you might think that generally individuals that … \[ outcome = \beta_0 + \beta_1(sex_i) + \beta(age_i) + error_i \] 6.1.4 Multi-level v2 For example you might think that generally individuals that … \[ outcome = \beta_0 + \beta_1(sex_i) + \beta(age_i) + error_i \]

Chapter 7 NZ Beech Forests The first beech forest paper assumes and tests the following process: \[log(N) = Control + Valley + Rats + Control:Rats\] \[r_{j,t} = \beta_{0,s,v,c} + \beta_{1,s,v,c} (S_{j,t})+ \beta_{2,s,v,c} (N_{j,t-1}) + \beta_{3,s,v,c} (R_{j,t-1})\] 7.1 Draft ideas 7.1.1 v1 7.1.2 v2 7.1.3 v3
